description:
Populus euphratica, commonly known as the Euphrates Poplar or the Desert Poplar, is a species of tree belonging to the genus Populus, which is part of the willow family (Salicaceae). This tree is native to Central Asia, the Middle East, and North Africa, thriving in arid and semi-arid regions.

Populus euphratica is a drought-tolerant and salt-tolerant tree species, well-adapted to the harsh environmental conditions of its native habitats. It can grow up to 20 meters in height and develop a twisted, gnarled trunk with distinctive peeling bark. The leaves of the Euphrates Poplar are highly variable, ranging from linear to ovate or lobed, depending on the tree's age and environmental conditions.

This species plays an important role in the ecosystems it inhabits, providing valuable ecosystem services such as soil stabilization, water conservation, and habitat for various wildlife species. Populus euphratica is considered a keystone species in the riparian and desert environments of its native range, contributing to the overall biodiversity and resilience of these fragile ecosystems.

Due to its adaptability and economic importance, Populus euphratica has been the subject of extensive research, particularly in the areas of drought and salt tolerance, as well as its potential for use in afforestation and land reclamation projects in arid and semi-arid regions.
